caption_text: (10) In Fig. 2 the expressions (dXc/dr) and (1/1-Xc) (dXc/dr) are plotted vs Xc when (dXc/dr) first in- creases, reaches a maximum and then decreases, whereas (1/1 - Xc) (dXcldr) increases strongly, later less strongly—over the whole range of Xc. This behaviour can be explained by the changes in accessible internal surface during the burn-off of the char. Wicke and Hedden[6] came to the same conclusion in studies of the gasification of pure carbon with COi at 1000°C.

caption_text: Reactivities of carbon to steam and hydrogen 169 ditionally they showed that the effective internal surface first increases with carbon conversion, reaches a maxi- mum value in the same range of burn-off as that for the maximum value of reaction rate, and then decreases at higher carbon conversions (Fig. 3). Different results have been obtained from our iso- thermal and non-isothermal studies using coals and chars prepared at temperatures below the temperature of gasification [7]. A differential reactor was used and the reaction rate was determined from amounts and analyses of product gases.

caption_text: As an example, Fig. 5 is an Arrhenius-diagram of a non-isothermal experiment from which, at temperatures greater than 800°C, the change from chemical control to pore diffusion control of rate can be seen [9]. Further, Table 1 shows some values of apparent activation ener- gies and frequency factors (according to eqns 11 and 14) for the reaction of lignites and hard coals with steam at a pressure of 40 bar [10]. The lignite (Rheinische Braun- kohle) and other lignites, have a low apparent activation energy and therefore high reactivites to steam.

caption_text: For comparison the reactivity r'c of coal with hydrogen at 900°C[13] at pressures of 30-70 bar is shown in Fig. 7 as a function of time. During the first 18 min when the coal is heated under hydrogen at a constant heating rate of 50°C/min, the reactivity increases. Afterwards we observe the decrease of reac- tivity expected from eqn (16) and Fig. 6 at constant temperature.

caption_text: Non-isothermal gasifications of coal and char in hydrogen and steam, and in hydrogen-steam mixtures, are reported in Fig. 8 [9]. The left graph of Fig. 8 shows that at low gasification temperatures, corresponding to low carbon conversions, the reactivity of the char with hydrogen is higher than that with steam and that those with mixtures of hydrogen and steam are between these values. This is caused by a large proportion of reactive carbon from the coal which results in the r.h.s.
raw_window: Non-isothermal gasifications of coal and char in hydrogen and steam, and in hydrogen-steam mixtures, are reported in Fig. 8 [9].

The left graph of Fig. 8 shows that at low gasification temperatures, corresponding to low carbon conversions, the reactivity of the char with hydrogen is higher than that with steam and that those with mixtures of hydrogen and steam are between these values.
This is caused by a large proportion of reactive carbon from the coal which results in the r.h.s.

caption_text: of Fig. 8, that at higher temperatures the reactivity of steam is higher than that of hydrogen and that in mixtures of steam with hydrogen the reactivity decreases with increasing hydrogen content. When the char is gasified (r.h.s. of Fig. 8) there is little reactive carbon present, and we find that inhibition of the steam-carbon reaction by hydrogen is more effective than the enhancement of overall reaction rate by the parallel hydrogasification reaction whose rate is relatively low.
raw_window: of Fig. 8, that at higher temperatures the reactivity of steam is higher than that of hydrogen and that in mixtures of steam with hydrogen the reactivity decreases with increasing hydrogen content.
When the char is gasified (r.h.s.

of Fig. 8) there is little reactive carbon present, and we find that inhibition of the steam-carbon reaction by hydrogen is more effective than the enhancement of overall reaction rate by the parallel hydrogasification reaction whose rate is relatively low.

caption_text: In the first process (Fig. 9) there is a pyrolysis zone on the top of the reactor in which coal is slowly heated. In the upper part of the gasification zone the hydrogen concentration is relatively high so that the freshly generated char, containing a high proportion of reactive carbon, is in an atmosphere of high hydrogen partial pressure. Therefore a high rate of hydrogasification can be expected in this part of the gasifier and, according to the l.h.s.
raw_window: In the first process (Fig. 9) there is a pyrolysis zone on the top of the reactor in which coal is slowly heated.

In the upper part of the gasification zone the hydrogen concentration is relatively high so that the freshly generated char, containing a high proportion of reactive carbon, is in an atmosphere of high hydrogen partial pressure.
Therefore a high rate of hydrogasification can be expected in this part of the gasifier and, according to the l.h.s.

caption_text: of Fig. 8, the overall reaction rate will increase with increasing hydrogen partial pressure in the gas mixture. If the total pressure of the system is increased a further increase of overall reaction rate is possible (eqn 17 and Fig. 7). Relatively the rate of the carbon-steam reaction does not rise according to Fig. 1 and eqn (7).
raw_window: of Fig. 8, the overall reaction rate will increase with increasing hydrogen partial pressure in the gas mixture.
If the total pressure of the system is increased a further increase of overall reaction rate is possible (eqn 17 and Fig. 7).
Relatively the rate of the carbon-steam reaction does not rise according to Fig. 1 and eqn (7).

caption_text: On the contrary, in the fluidized bed process (Fig. 10) the heating rate is fast and therefore the proportion of reactive carbon is relatively small. Due to backmixing of solids in the gasifier no preferential reaction of freshly formed char with hydrogen can be expected. On the other hand there is a concentration profile in the gas phase over the height of the fluidized bed.
raw_window: On the contrary, in the fluidized bed process (Fig. 10) the heating rate is fast and therefore the proportion of reactive carbon is relatively small.
Due to backmixing of solids in the gasifier no preferential reaction of freshly formed char with hydrogen can be expected.
On the other hand there is a concentration profile in the gas phase over the height of the fluidized bed.

caption_text: Several gasification reactions are given as a simplified model in Table 2, where the reactions of volatiles from coal and of so-called reactive carbon formed during pyrolysis are fast and are in parallel with the slow reaction of the usually non-reactive carbon from char [14].
raw_window: Several gasification reactions are given as a simplified model in Table 2, where the reactions of volatiles from coal and of so-called reactive carbon formed during pyrolysis are fast and are in parallel with the slow reaction of the usually non-reactive carbon from char [14].
There are several ways of describing these reactions as a function of the carbon conversion, e.g.

by assuming two parallel first order reactions with different rate constants accord- ing to dA'< re = -^ = k,(f - Xc) + fed - Xc) for Xc < f rc=df^=W-Xc) for Xc>f (15) with ki > ki, f = proportion of reactive carbon; or by assuming an activation energy decreasing with Ac for which we can use the following expression: rc=k^ï-Xc)(ï+be-''xc).

caption_text: Table 3 shows that the mean reactivity of coals and chars in hydrogen-steam mixtures is lower than in pure steam [9], the effect increasing with decreasing volatile content in the coal or char. The highest inhibition of reaction rate by hydrogen is found when we used a residual char from a Semitechnical hydrogasification plant.
raw_window: Table 3 shows that the mean reactivity of coals and chars in hydrogen-steam mixtures is lower than in pure steam [9], the effect increasing with decreasing volatile content in the coal or char.
The highest inhibition of reaction rate by hydrogen is found when we used a residual char from a Semitechnical hydrogasification plant.
table_reason: S0 and S1 together form a coherent caption describing the table content, while S2 is a section number unrelated to the caption.

caption_text: High rates of heating of coal cause a decrease in the proportion of reactive carbon because of conversion of reactive carbon into unreactive carbon (reaction lib in Table 2) is faster than the hydrogasification of the reactive carbon (reaction lia).
raw_window: High rates of heating of coal cause a decrease in the proportion of reactive carbon because of conversion of reactive carbon into unreactive carbon (reaction lib in Table 2) is faster than the hydrogasification of the reactive carbon (reaction lia).

Efficient interaction between a freshly formed char and hydrogen is more favourable in moving bed reactors with countercurrent stream of gas and solid than in fluidized beds with high back-mixing of solids.

Processes in which significant gasification takes place in the temperature range of chemical control involve gasification under pressure in a moving bed with a coun- Raw gas • 6-40 mm Hz CO CO;CH4 vol '/.
